channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Washington Post’s Business Struggles as Frustrations Mount
item.description: With digital subscriptions and digital advertising revenue stagnating, the company is on a pace to lose money this year.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
item.media:description: Fred Ryan, the chief executive and publisher of The Washington Post, with Sally Buzbee, the executive editor, left.

item.title: This Remote Mine Could Foretell the Future of America’s Electric Car Industry
item.description: Hiding a thousand feet below the earth’s surface in this patch of northern Minnesota wetlands are ancient mineral deposits that some view as critical to fueling America’s clean energy future.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tim Gruber
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times

item.title: How German Companies Are Staring Down Putin’s Threat to Cut Off Gas
item.description: Industrial producers across Germany are coming up with unique ways to cut their dependence on natural gas as Russia’s war in Ukraine keeps prices high.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A power plant burning coal in Wilhelmshaven, Germany. Coal-fired plants, many of which were destined to be shut down, have been revived by manufacturers seeking an alternative to expensive Russian natural gas.

item.title: Google Employee Who Played Key Role in Protest of Contract With Israel Quits
item.description: The worker said the company had tried to retaliate against her activism opposing a deal with the Israeli military, while co-workers argued the company had an anti-Palestinian bias.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant
item.category: From the River to the Sea: Palestine and Israel in the Shadow of "Peace" (Book)
item.media:credit: Geloy Concepcion for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ariel Koren, a marketing manager at Google, opposed Project Nimbus because she was concerned that the company’s technology could help the Israeli Defense Forces surveil and harm Palestinians.

item.title: Google Says Trump’s Truth Social Must Scrub Violent Content to Join Play Store
item.description: The social media app is not available on Google’s app store, and the former president’s company and Google are publicly disagreeing about why.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant

item.title: Sweeping Children’s Online Safety Bill Is Passed in California
item.description: The new rules, which would require many online services to increase protections for children, could change how popular social media and game platforms treat minors.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:description: Proponents of the bill say the new rules should reduce risks for minors while promoting children’s autonomy and well-being online.

item.title: Lockdowns in China, and North Korea, Deal Double Blow to Bridge City
item.description: Shenyang, in China’s northeast, was a hub for North Korean workers and a launchpad for visits to Pyongyang. Covid restrictions have battered its economy.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Food stalls in Shenyang’s Koreatown. The city used to be a crucial link between China and North Korea, but the pandemic changed that.

item.title: Elon Musk Cites Twitter Whistleblower Report as Reason to Scrap Deal
item.description: The billionaire said in a letter to Twitter that allegations made by a whistle-blower have had a “material, if not existential” effect on the company.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch and Kate Conger
item.media:description: Elon Musk has said Twitter’s disclosures about the number of fake accounts on the platform were misleading.

item.title: California Approves Bill to Punish Doctors Who Spread False Information
item.description: Weighing into the fierce national debate over Covid-19 prevention and treatments, the state would be the first to try a legal remedy for vaccine disinformation.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: California’s Legislature approved a bill that would allow regulators to punish doctors for spreading false information about Covid-19 vaccinations and treatments.

item.title: Russia Halts Natural Gas Flows to Germany Again
item.description: Gazprom said the Nord Stream 1 pipeline would undergo three days of maintenance, raising worries about a complete shutdown of Russian gas deliveries to Germany.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:description: Part of the Nord Stream 1 pipeline in Lubmin, Germany.

item.title: Job Openings Picked Up in July, Showing the Labor Market Remains Hot
item.description: Even with the Fed raising interest rates, employers are still eager to hire.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith
item.media:description: A waitress during lunch hour at a restaurant in Manhattan.

item.title: Paxlovid Cuts Covid Deaths Among Older People, Israeli Study Finds
item.description: Among patients under 65, however, the drug made little difference in hospitalization or death rates.
item.dc:creator: Roni Rabin
item.media:description: According to the new Israeli study, the medication was highly effective when administered to individuals 65 and over.

item.title: French Tax Collectors Use A.I. to Spot Thousands of Undeclared Pools
item.description: Algorithms combing through satellite photos found over 20,000 unreported swimming pools in a few regions, yielding an expected $10 million in taxes, and the system will soon go nationwide.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Francois Lo Presti/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Installing a swimming pool in northern France this month. The French government is using new technology to crack down on homeowners who fail to register pools to avoid higher property taxes.

item.title: First Solar says it will spend up to $1.2 billion to expand U.S. production.
item.description: The solar panel maker will build a factory in the Southeast and expand three Ohio plants, creating nearly 1,000 jobs.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:description: A First Solar factory in Perrysburg, Ohio. The solar panel manufacturer’s plans to expand its factories arrive on the heels of the Inflation Reduction Act.

item.title: California Bill Bids for Tighter Rein on Fast-Food Chains
item.description: The bill, which would create a state council to establish minimum pay and safety conditions, was the subject of a giant lobbying battle.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Bernhard Warner and Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:description: A swift and sweeping blow to fast-food companies.

item.title: Government Will Cancel $1.5 Billion in Loans for Westwood College Students
item.description: The Education Department intends to wipe out the federal debt of those who attended the for-profit school from 2002 until it closed in 2016 without requiring them to apply.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and Education Secretary Miguel Cardona speaking about loan forgiveness last week in Washington.

item.title: From Red Lobster to Running Some of New York’s Marquee Restaurants
item.description: Chip Wade takes over Danny Meyer’s role in running Union Square Hospitality Group, a move that signals a growing conversation between two sides of the industry.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson
item.media:credit: Timothy O'Connell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chip Wade, the newly minted chief executive officer of the Union Square Hospitality Group, visits Marta, one of the company’s New York restaurants.

item.title: Biden’s Student Loan Plan Sets Off Fierce Debate Among Economists
item.description: Liberals and more moderate Democrats are arguing over the impact on inflation, the federal budget deficit and high earners.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden announced his student loan forgiveness plan with Education Secretary Miguel A. Cardona last week.

item.title: Uma Pemmaraju, an Original Fox News Channel Anchor, Dies at 64
item.description: She convinced her Indian parents to allow her to pursue journalism as a career, then went on to win three Emmy Awards.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Uma Pemmaraju in 2016. In her nearly 20 years at the Fox News Channel she hosted programs like “Fox News Now,” “Fox on Trends,” the Sunday edition of “Fox News Live” and “The Fox Report.”

item.title: California Senate Passes Bill to Regulate Fast-Food Industry
item.description: If signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom, the measure would create a state council to establish minimum pay and safety conditions on an industrywide basis.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:description: Supporters of a bill that would regulate working conditions in the fast-food industry marched in Sacramento this month.

item.title: An Orlando Museum’s Disputed Basquiats Are Gone. Its Leadership Is, Too.
item.description: In the wake of an F.B.I. raid, the crisis at the Orlando Museum of Art deepened amid upheaval on its board and the resignation of its interim director.
item.dc:creator: Brett Sokol
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Orlando Museum of Art is facing a crisis, with five board members ousted and an interim director who resigned suddenly.

item.title: FTC Sues Over Tracking Data That Could Expose Visits to Abortion Clinics
item.description: Federal regulators said the sale of geolocation information on tens of millions of smartphones could expose people’s visits to private places.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:description: Civil rights groups have warned that law enforcement agencies could obtain smartphone locations of women seeking abortions and use the data to prosecute them.

item.title: Buy Now, Pay Later: Going Into Debt for Groceries
item.description: Americans are increasingly turning to “buy now, pay later” services for food and other everyday essentials. And there are signs that the practice is putting some in deep debt.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna
item.media:credit: Chona Kasinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Buy now, pay later” services, which allow consumers to pay for goods in installments, often without interest, have become increasingly common for food purchases.

item.title: Be ‘Less Squeamish’ About Drinking Recycled Wastewater, British Official Says
item.description: As droughts become more frequent, drinking water that has been reprocessed from sewage treatment is the future, the head of Britain’s Environment Agency said.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: A sewage treatment plant in Rickmansworth, England. Toilet-to-tap recycling is “perfectly safe and healthy, but not something many people fancy,” the head of Britain’s Environment Agency wrote this week.

item.title: It’s Not Just You — Blank Street Coffee Is Suddenly Inescapable
item.description: Built around high-volume automated espresso systems, the rapidly expanding coffee shop has caught the attention of skeptical New Yorkers.
item.dc:creator: Julia Moskin
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
item.media:description: In just two years, the Blank Street coffee chain expanded from this tiny cart to 40 locations in New York City and five in London.

item.title: Air France Under Scrutiny Over Safety Incidents
item.description: Two pilots have recently been suspended after a cockpit fight, bringing to light new concerns over poorly observed safety protocols at the French airline.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: News of the altercation between two pilots while they were airborne has brought to light broader safety issues at Air France.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Lawyers Subpoena Twitter Whistle-Blower
item.description: Peiter Zatko’s accusations of false statements and security shortcomings at Twitter may be used by Mr. Musk in the legal battle over a $44 billion acquisition of the company.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Elon Musk has said Twitter’s disclosures about the number of fake accounts on the platform were misleading.

item.title: Honda and LG will jointly build a U.S. battery plant.
item.description: The announcement comes as the auto industry ramps up its efforts to switch to electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: A Honda electric vehicle on display at the Central China Auto Show last month.

item.title: Lawmakers Seek Information on ‘Buy Now, Pay Later’ Gun Sales
item.description: Eighteen Democrats in Congress are demanding answers from Credova Financial about its no-interest loans for gun and ammunition purchases.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein

item.title: How a Whistleblower Could Help Elon Musk in His Case Against Twitter
item.description: Twitter’s former security chief could loom large in Mr. Musk’s legal efforts to undo his $44 billion acquisition of the social network.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Bernhard Warner, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Calling on Mudge?

item.title: Low Water Levels Disrupt European River Cruises, a Favorite of U.S. Tourists
item.description: As the continent faces a severe drought, companies have had to use buses to transport passengers along parts of the Rhine and the Danube, where water levels have become too low for riverboats.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: A tourist vessel cruised in the partially dried up riverbed of the Rhine River in Bingen, Germany, in August.

item.title: The Fed’s inflation warning reverberates in global markets.
item.description: Stocks slipped across Asia and Europe, and futures pointed to a downward opening on Wall Street.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Recycled Metals From Electronic Waste Used to Make Jewelry
item.description: More jewelers, large and small, are using precious metals recovered from electronic waste.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Bumpus

item.title: How Quitting a Job Changed My Relationships
item.description: We asked people who quit during the “Great Resignation” how it helped them reconnect with their loved ones. This is what they told us.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Needelman
item.media:credit: Leah Nash for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ana del Rocío with her sons, Tupac, left, and Inti, at their home in Portland, Ore. Ms. del Rocío left her job as executive director of a nonprofit to spend more time with her children.

item.title: Silicon Valley’s Elite Get Dragged Into Musk-Twitter Trial
item.description: More than 100 subpoenas have been issued to techies like Jack Dorsey and Marc Andreessen as Twitter tries to force Elon Musk to complete a $44 billion deal. Law firms are stoked.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger

item.title: In ‘Little Venice,’ Cruise Ships and an Influx of Tourists
item.description: With a ban on large cruise ships in the waters surrounding Venice, nearby Chioggia is one of the new go-to ports. While many welcome the new visitors, some worry that the tourism boom could turn sour.
item.dc:creator: Anna Momigliano
item.media:credit: Susan Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: The cruise ship Viking Sea in Chioggia’s port. Following a series of protests from environmental groups last year, the Italian government recently started enforcing a ban on large cruise ships from the portion of the lagoon surrounding Venice’s historic center. Chioggia is now one of the alternative ports.

item.title: Manhattan Has a Glut of Empty Offices. Hochul Wants to Build More.
item.description: Despite near record-high office vacancies, Gov. Kathy Hochul has backed a real estate project at the New York transit hub that would be one of the largest in American history.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag, Patrick McGeehan and Andres Kudacki
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times

item.title: Revenge of the Founders: A Generational Struggle on Wall Street
item.description: The abrupt departure of Kewsong Lee as Carlyle Group’s chief executive followed conflicts over how to run the financial firm.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Farrell and Peter Eavis
item.media:description: Kewsong Lee, the former chief executive of the Carlyle Group.

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Vision for Tech Self-Reliance in China Runs Into Reality
item.description: After heavy national investment in semiconductors to break a dependence on global chips, Mr. Xi seems unhappy with the results.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

item.title: Rick Reed, G.O.P. Adman of ‘Swift Boat’ Campaign, Dies at 69
item.description: In helping to create a series of ads attacking the Democratic presidential candidate John Kerry’s military record, he added a new term to the political lexicon.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan
item.media:description: Rick Reed helped produce ads during the 2004 campaign that attacked the war record of Senator John Kerry, who was running for president.

item.title: The Week in Business: Changing Consumer Habits
item.description: Peloton struggles to emerge from the pandemic. The Federal Reserve chair issues a warning from Jackson Hole. Economists await August’s jobs report.
item.dc:creator: Marie Solis

item.title: ‘Wood Is Life’: A Hong Kong Sawmill’s Last Days
item.description: Chi Kee Sawmill and Timber, in business since the 1940s, will soon make way for a vast development project. But it is still bringing new life to old wood.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Louise Delmotte
item.media:credit: Louise Delmotte for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wong Hung Kuen, the owner of Chi Kee Sawmill and Lumber in Hong Kong, which is slated to be demolished in mid-September.

item.title: Trying to Keep Americans Camping With Treehouses and Yurts
item.description: Interest in camping soared in the pandemic, and now, as social-distancing restrictions are winding down, the sector is showing signs that it may maintain its popularity.
item.dc:creator: Seth Berkman and Mike Belleme
item.media:description: Guest cabins at Yogi Bear’s Jellystone Park in Bostic, N.C. Campgrounds are adding accommodations akin to those found at resorts.

item.title: The Office’s Last Stand
item.description: It’s either the end of the era of flexibility around where work takes place — or the beginning of outright rebellion.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
item.media:description: The coffee bar at Credit Karma office in Oakland, Calif.

item.title: One Man’s Dream of Fusing A.I. With Common Sense
item.description: Artificial intelligence systems can process vast amounts of data in seconds, but they can’t make sense of the world or explain their decisions. David Ferrucci wants to change that.
item.dc:creator: Steve Lohr
item.media:credit: Casey Steffens for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Ferrucci worked for the hedge fund Bridgewater Associates before starting his company.

item.title: Abbott to Restart Production of Similac Baby Formula
item.description: The company said manufacturing would resume at a Michigan plant that had been shut over contamination concerns, which triggered a nationwide formula shortage.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden
item.media:description: With production of Similac set to resume at a plant in Sturgis, Mich., Abbott hopes to ease a formula shortage that left parents across the country scrambling.

item.title: Biden’s Big Dreams Meet the Limits of ‘Imperfect’ Tools
item.description: The student loan plan is the latest example of Democrats practicing the art of the possible on the nation’s most pressing economic challenges and ending up with risky or patchwork solutions.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s plan to cancel some student loan debt could help millions of borrowers, but economists warn that it could also spur even faster tuition increases.

item.title: Planning for Your Retirement, and for a Child’s Special Needs, All at Once
item.description: People with children who cannot support themselves need to think well past their own lifetime and figure out how to provide for children after they are gone.
item.dc:creator: Martha C. White

item.title: Does Watching College Football on TV Have to Be So Miserable?
item.description: The corporations that control these broadcasts know: It can still be hugely lucrative to provide an experience that fans come to despise.
item.dc:creator: Ben Mathis-Lilley

item.title: How Will the Student Loan Forgiveness Plan Affect You?
item.description: We want to hear about what President Biden’s debt cancellation plan means for your life and finances.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times

item.title: Don’t Skip Therapy Because of Work
item.description: And other tips on asking for what you need, and making it clear when it’s a demand and not a question.
item.dc:creator: Roxane Gay
item.media:credit: Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: NBC Discusses Ending Prime-Time Lineup at 10 p.m.
item.description: Even the consideration of such a move shows the waning influence of traditional broadcast TV.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin

item.title: Steven Hoffenberg, Debt Baron Who Ran a Vast Fraud, Dies at 77
item.description: A onetime business associate of Jeffrey Epstein who briefly controlled The New York Post, he spent 18 years in prison for a $460 million Ponzi scheme.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Steven Hoffenberg in January 1993, when he was trying to buy The New York Post. “I’ve made millions,” he said at the time. “Now I want to have some excitement.”

item.title: Lessons From a Cannabis Farmer
item.description: Rainforest music, Willie Nelson, subterranean greenhouses: A cannabis farmer shares trade secrets.
item.dc:creator: Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg

item.title: How the U.K. Energy Price Cap Works
item.description: A U.K. regulator determines how much utilities can charge customers. The latest increase is almost entirely due to higher wholesale energy costs.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.category: Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (Ofgem) (Great Britain)
item.media:description: Ofgem, the British energy regulator, sets a price per unit of natural gas and electricity.

item.title: To Make Money in the Stock Market, Do Nothing
item.description: The bear market endures, yet the S&P 500 index rose more than 17 percent from mid-June to mid-August. Don’t even try to guess what will happen next, our columnist says.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer

item.title: Fed Chair Signals More Rate Increases Ahead, Shaking Wall Street
item.description: The Federal Reserve chair pledged to resolutely fight rapid price increases, arguing the bigger mistake would be allowing inflation to become entrenched.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: “Restoring price stability will take some time and requires using our tools forcefully to bring demand and supply into better balance,” Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, told a Fed conference in Wyoming Friday.

item.title: Watch live: Jerome Powell speaks at the Fed’s Jackson Hole conference.
